channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Apple launches “Time to Walk” fitness service with celebrity guests
item.description: Dolly Parton, Shawn Mendes, and more lend their voices to the first episodes.

item.title: SpaceX set to launch its next Starship prototype on Monday
item.description: It’s only been about six weeks since SN8 flew.

item.title: “I can’t tell you how much vaccine we have,” new CDC head says
item.description: Biden admin officials work to manage expectations on topsy-turvy vaccine rollout.

item.title: The secret to this $5,000 electric motorcycle is a cast aluminum frame
item.description: The Sondors Metacycle will have a range of 80 miles and a top speed of 85mph.

item.title: Google Maps will soon show COVID vaccine locations
item.description: Vaccine site listings will show access requirements and appointment info.

item.title: Egyptian archaeologists unearth dozens of tombs at Saqqara necropolis
item.description: The graves may belong to people who worshipped the pharaoh Teti, buried nearby.

item.title: Valve’s Gabe Newell imagines “editing” personalities with future headsets
item.description: “Remember when Bob got hacked by Russian malware [and] ran naked through forests?”

item.title: The history of the connected battlespace, part one: command, control, and conquer
item.description: Since the end of World War II, the US and allies have tried to network-enable war.

item.title: Godzilla vs. Kong trailer is a rock ‘em, sock ’em monster mashup
item.description: Directed by Adam Wingard, it’s the fourth installment in the “MonsterVerse” franchise

item.title: A curious observer’s guide to quantum mechanics, pt. 3: Rose colored glasses
item.description: “How big is a particle?” Well, that’s a subtle (and, unsurprisingly, complex) question.

item.title: Review: Lupin updates classic French gentleman thief for the 21st century
item.description: Omar Sy heads stellar cast in clever series inspired by the works of Maurice Leblanc

item.title: SpaceX launches 143 satellites into orbit, most ever [Updated]
item.description: Party in the payload bay: 143 total satellites deployed in a dozen waves.

item.title: Is this a fossilized lair of the dreaded bobbit worm?
item.description: The giant worms hunted in pretty much the most nightmarish way possible.

item.title: DDoSers are abusing Microsoft RDP to make attacks more powerful
item.description: DDoS amplification attacks have abused all kinds of legit services. Now, it’s Windows.

item.title: What’s the technology behind a five-minute charge battery?
item.description: The company behind a new battery isn’t saying much, but we figured a few things out.

item.title: The art and science of boarding an airplane in a pandemic
item.description: Researchers and airlines obsessed over efficiency now worry about safety, too.

item.title: This site posted every face from Parler’s Capitol Hill insurrection videos
item.description: Faces of the Riot used open source software to detect, extract, and deduplicate every face.

item.title: What happens to the brain on sudden impact? Egg yolks could hold the answer
item.description: Rotational deceleration causes most deformation—like getting punched on the chin

item.title: Waymo CEO dismisses Tesla self-driving plan: “This is not how it works”
item.description: Elon Musk and John Krafcik have very different theories about driverless tech.

item.title: Blizzard absorbs acclaimed Activision studio as a dedicated “support” team [Updated]
item.description: Vicarious Visions impressed with Tony Hawk 1+2. Now? Possibly a Diablo II remake.

item.title: Military intelligence buys location data instead of getting warrants, memo shows
item.description: A long and growing list of agencies are using money to bypass Carpenter ruling.

item.title: Home alarm tech backdoored security cameras to spy on customers having sex
item.description: Employee for ADT accessed ~200 customer cams on more than 9,600 occasions.

item.title: How desperate are you for GPUs, CPUs, consoles? Newegg tests with new lottery
item.description: System counters (some) issues with scalpers, inventory, but are the hoops worth it?

item.title: Google: We’ll shut down Australian search before we pay news sites for links
item.description: Tim Berners-Lee says Aussie law would break a fundamental principle of the Web.

item.title: Report: The MacBook Air is getting a major redesign, too
item.description: Also, a bit of a bombshell: The new MacBook Pro will have an SD card slot.

item.title: CenturyLink, Frontier missed FCC broadband deadlines in dozens of states
item.description: US law gives the ISPs one extra year before they have to forfeit money.

item.title: Loon’s bubble bursts—Alphabet shuts down Internet balloon company
item.description: After eight years, Loon couldn’t find a “long-term, sustainable business.”

item.title: Today’s best tech deals: Apple Magic Keyboard, Assassin’s Creed Valhalla, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has wireless headphones, security cameras, and microSD cards.

item.title: Xbox Live price increase reversed after less than one day [Updated]
item.description: “We messed up today and you were right to let us know.” Plus, a major F2P update.

item.title: Chrome and Edge want to help with that password problem of yours
item.description: The line between browsers and password managers is blurring.

item.title: Rocket Report: Starship going offshore, Blue Origin may launch humans in April
item.description: “We’re smarter as a team having been through this process.”

item.title: A look at all of Biden’s changes to energy and environmental regulations
item.description: There’s a lot going on in addition to some of Biden’s high-profile moves.

item.title: Resident Evil VIII gets May release date, massive preview, playable demo
item.description: A free no-combat demo goes live on PlayStation 5 today; will hit Xbox, PC later.

item.title: “Complete incompetence:” Biden team slams Trump’s COVID work
item.description: Biden Administration starts off with a flurry of orders, actions, and comprehensive plan.

item.title: Parler’s attempt to get back on Amazon Web Services rejected by judge
item.description: Judge denies injunction motion, says Parler’s claims against Amazon are weak.

item.title: Google agrees to pay French news sites to send them traffic
item.description: The French agreement could become a template for similar deals across Europe.

item.title: Facebook calls in its Oversight Board to rule on Trump ban
item.description: Facebook finally made a judgement call; now wants someone else to decide if it was right

item.title: Democrat Jessica Rosenworcel replaces Ajit Pai, is now acting FCC chairwoman
item.description: Net neutrality supporter Rosenworcel leads FCC on at least an interim basis.

item.title: Phishing scam had all the bells and whistles—except for one
item.description: A reminder that stuff published on the Internet gets published on the Internet.

item.title: Ars online IT roundtable: What’s the future of the data center?
item.description: Join Sean Gallagher, Dell’s Ivan Nekrasov, and me today, January 21, at 3:15pm Eastern!

item.title: Ubuntu Linux is now running on M1 Macs
item.description: We still have a way to go before easily dual-booting Linux and macOS.

item.title: Samsung is making “very large quantities” of 90Hz OLED displays for laptops
item.description: Samsung Display says several customers are shipping 90Hz OLED laptops this year.

item.title: Ars Technicast special edition, part 1: The Internet of Things goes to war
item.description: Ars presents a two-part limited edition podcast on the “connected battlespace.”

item.title: GamersNexus’ Steve Burke overclocks his YouTube channel’s best comments
item.description: Learn the true secrets of thermal paste application from the Six Billion Hertz Man.

item.title: QAnon in crisis as day of reckoning fails to materialize
item.description: Pro-Trump cult believed election results would be violently overturned on January 20.

item.title: Report: Apple’s VR headset will be a pricey, high-end niche standalone
item.description: High-res displays, M1-beating processors, and prescription lenses could push up cost.

item.title: One of Biden’s first climate actions looks at fuel efficiency rollback
item.description: The EPA has to consider “suspending, revising, or rescinding” the weaker rules.

item.title: Three rows, 37mpg, and under $34,000? The 2021 Kia Sorento Hybrid
item.description: We think the Sorento Hybrid will be in high demand.

item.title: Treasury nominee Yellen is looking to curtail use of cryptocurrency
item.description: Yellen argues many cryptocurrencies are used “mainly for illicit financing.”

item.title: New metamaterial merges magnetic memory and physical changes
item.description: A mix of actuator and bit-level memory.

item.title: Twitch’s Trump ban sustained after leaving office
item.description: Video-streaming account launched in 2019, faced first suspension in 2020.

item.title: Amazon offers Biden help to speed up vaccine distribution
item.description: A huge number of Amazon’s own 800,000 employees are considered essential workers.

item.title: PC fan port of early Sonic games lets you zoom the camera way, way out
item.description: This is quite literally Sonic like you’ve never seen him before.

item.title: Security firm Malwarebytes was infected by same hackers who hit SolarWinds
item.description: Group backed by a nation-state rifles through company’s email servers.

item.title: 3Mbps uploads still fast enough for US homes, Ajit Pai says in final report
item.description: Pai’s last report keeps 6-year-old broadband standard and gives ISPs high marks.
